title: Kenya: Counties Yet to Embrace Online Tendering
text:
Lack of e-procurement use by local counties has also been felt by Deputy President William Ruto who last week urged the 47 County Governments to enhance the system use so as to improve efficiency in their procurement. 
PERSONNEL DEPLOYED 
Mr Ruto told governors that a lot of ground work had been undertaken towards ensuring that e-procurement works across all counties. 
Integrated Financial Management Systems (IFMIS) Director Jerome Ochieng', however, said over 4,000 government agencies and their suppliers were trained in July on how to use the system. 
He added that there is a dedicated link to every county with personnel deployed on the ground to monitor progress. In cases where downtimes occur, modems are supplied to fill the gap. 
"Sometimes vandalism majorly caused by road and building constructions interfere with the network flow but we are quick to respond," added Mr Ochieng'. 
TRAINING OFFICIALS 
The National Treasury has been in consultation with the committee in charge of Finance within the Council of Governors to figure out modalities of getting counties to use the system for all their procurement. 
The Treasury, together with the Committee, have also undertaken training of officials in different counties to ensure there are no skills gaps that would hamper the effective operating of the e-procurement system. 
"All government procurement will be carried out under this framework. The necessary consultations have been done between Treasury, the management of IFMIS and the County Governments that will ensure that all staff and eventually the Governors will be brought on board to provide greater understanding of e-procurement," said Ruto when he chaired an extraordinary session of Intergovernmental Budget and Economic Council's (IBEC) last week.
